facts.text: Charge-sheet issued to appellant on April 23, 1960 by Station Manager containing two charges of gross dereliction of duty for mistakes in preparation of load-sheet on one day and balance chart on another day, which might have led to serious aircraft accident.
Appellant replied to charge-sheet on April 26, 1960 admitting the mistakes but contended he was over-worked and it was duty of others to check load-sheet and balance chart.
Inquiry fixed for May 9, 1960 by Station Manager; appellant objected on ground of bias due to evidence given by appellant against Station Manager in customs case leading to fine on Station Manager.
Objection to inquiry by Station Manager over-ruled; inquiry held by Station Manager and completed on May 10, 1960.
Station Manager forwarded findings and recommendations to Regional Representative of respondent-company.
Appellant dismissed on May 28, 1960 by Regional Representative; order provided for payment of one month's wages and stated application being made to First Industrial Tribunal for approval.
Order of dismissal communicated to appellant on May 30, 1960; one month's wages tendered but not accepted.
Respondent filed application before First Industrial Tribunal under s.33(2)(b) on May 30, 1960 seeking approval.
Appellant made application under s.33A on June 3, 1960 challenging legality of dismissal on various grounds.

Second Labour Court, West Bengal, by award dated June 22, 1961, held dismissal justified, approved action under s.33(2)(b), found no need for prior permission under s.33(1), appellant not protected workman, even if bias violation of natural justice, dismissal justified on evidence; mistakes serious, no victimisation.
Mistakes committed by appellant in January and March 1960; Station Manager knew a few days before charge-sheet.

Letter from Vice-President of union to Manager mentioning appellant as joint secretary and requesting recognition as protected workman; company replied pointing legal defects; no further evidence of recognition.

legal_issues.text: Whether application under s.33(2)(b) was validly made as per proviso requiring simultaneous dismissal, payment of wages, and application.
Whether appellant was a protected workman requiring prior permission under s.33(3).
Whether Station Manager was biased violating principles of natural justice in domestic inquiry.
Whether there was victimisation of appellant.
Whether Labour Court could consider merits of dismissal despite defective inquiry, and whether approval relates back to date of dismissal order.

petitioner_arguments.text: Application under s.33(2)(b) invalid as not simultaneous with dismissal and payment.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Proviso to s.33(2)(b), Straw Board Manufacturing Co. v. Govind

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellant was protected workman; prior permission under s.33(3) required.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Rules for recognition of protected workmen

petitioner_arguments.text: Station Manager biased due to customs case evidence; violation of natural justice; Labour Court could not consider merits.
Victimisation due to delay in charge-sheet.
Dismissal should take effect from date of Labour Court award, not relate back.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sasa Musa Sugar Works v. Shobrati Khan

respondent_arguments.text: Application under s.33(2)(b) valid as dismissal order passed May 28, communicated May 30 with wages offered, application filed same day.
Appellant not protected workman; no recognition by employer.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: West Bengal Government rules on protected workmen

respondent_arguments.text: No violation of natural justice as mistakes admitted, inquiry formal; punishment by Regional Representative.
No victimisation; Station Manager knew of mistakes few days before charge-sheet; admission of mistakes.
Labour Court can go into merits despite defective inquiry; approval relates back.

court_reasoning.text: Application under s.33(2)(b) valid; dismissal May 28, communicated May 30 with wages offered same day, application filed same day; simultaneous as part of same transaction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Depends on circumstances; here satisfied per Straw Board case.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant not protected workman; question of fact, no evidence of employer recognition despite union letter.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Positive action by employer required per rules.

court_reasoning.text: Even assuming bias and violation of natural justice, Labour Court entitled to consider evidence and justify dismissal on merits per Phulbari Tea Estate.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tribunal can go into propriety despite defect.

court_reasoning.text: No victimisation; delay explained, mistakes admitted.
Where inquiry defective but dismissal ordered, Labour Court approval on merits relates back to dismissal date; distinguishes Sasa Musa (no prior inquiry or conclusion).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Approval relates back as employer held inquiry and ordered dismissal.

court_reasoning.text: Mistakes serious, possible aircraft accident and loss of life; dismissal not unconscionable.

holdings.text: Proviso to s.33(2)(b) requires dismissal, wages payment/offer, and application to be simultaneous parts of same transaction; here satisfied.
Protected workman status question of fact requiring employer recognition; none here, no prior permission needed.
Labour Court can adjudicate dismissal merits despite natural justice defect in domestic inquiry.
Approval of dismissal after defective inquiry but justified on evidence relates back to original dismissal date.

precedents_cited.case_name: Straw Board Manufacturing Co. Limited, Saharanpur v. Govind
precedents_cited.relevance: Proviso to s.33(2)(b) requires simultaneous action as part of same transaction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Phulbari Tea Estate v. Its workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Tribunal can decide on evidence whether action justified despite natural justice violation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Messrs. Sasa Musa Sugar Works Pvt. Ltd. v. Shobrati Khan
precedents_cited.relevance: Applies where no prior inquiry or dismissal conclusion; wages till s.33 decision.

precedents_cited.case_name: Management of Ranipur Colliery v. Bhuban Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Permission under s.33(1) relates back to date of employer's conclusion after inquiry.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs approval/permission for dismissal during pendency of industrial dispute; proviso to s.33(2)(b) for non-protected workmen; s.33A for challenge by employee.

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave dismissed; Labour Court's approval of dismissal upheld as justified; all contentions rejected including on s.33(2)(b) validity, protected status, bias, victimisation, and relation back of approval.

key_quotes.text: the proviso to s.33(2)(b) contemplates the three things mentioned therein, namely, (i) dismissal or discharge (ii) payment of wages, and (iii) making of an application for approval, to be simultaneous and to be part of the same transaction
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: it is not well settled by a number of decisions of this Court that it is open to the tribunal to go into the propriety of an order of dismissal itself, when there is a defect in the domestic inquiry.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Affirms Labour Court's power despite inquiry defect.

key_quotes.text: its approval of the order of dismissal made by the employer in a defective inquiry would still relate back to the date when the order was made.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding on effect of approval.
